etymologies: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin libraria ‘bookstore’, feminine (used as a noun) of librarius ‘relating to books’, from liber, libr- ‘book’

definitions: a building or room containing collections of books, periodicals, and sometimes films and recorded music for people to read, borrow, or refer to
shortDefinitions: building or room containing books etc.

definitions: a collection of books and periodicals held in a library

examples.text: the Institute houses an outstanding library of 35,000 volumes on the fine arts

definitions: a room in a private house where books are kept

examples.text: there was a library that Uncle Hilbert used as his study

definitions: a series of books, recordings, etc., issued by the same company and similar in appearance.
shortDefinitions: series of books issued as set

definitions: a collection of films, recorded music, genetic material, etc., organized systematically and kept for research or borrowing
a collection of programs and software packages made generally available, often loaded and stored on disk for immediate use

examples.text: download any of thousands of programs from our software libraries
